field_edited_text.value:
Planned Development

Private: The composition of the Fells
Point/Canton shoreline is rapidly changing.
This is evidenced by the following projects.

*The Anchorage: In late 1982 construc-
tion began on the Anchorage, a devel-
opment which in the first phase in-
cludes 40 townhouses overlooking a
public waterfront promenade and an 80
slip marina. The second phase of the
project includes construction of an ad-
dition 700 feet of the public prome-
nade, a 260 slip marina and yacht club
and a high-rise condominium. The pro-
menade will provide almost one-
quarter mile of public shoreline access.



*Thames Point: The Wolfe Street por-
tion of the former National Can Co.
plant has been renovated into approxi-
mately 32 rental units, with the first re-
served for commercial activity. A public
boardwalk and a small marina for 50
boats have also been developed. Work
has begun on Phase Il of the project
which will develop 87 additional units.

Henderson’s Wharf: The former B& O
warehouse on Fell Street and the adja-
cent tip of land that was the original
Fells Point have been awarded to a firm
to redevelop as a complex of apart-

| ments, inn, commercial space and a 225
slip marina. The shoreline around the
vacant parcel and the ground floor of
the building is to be a public prome-
nade. Development in the future could
expand to also include waterfront
townhouses and provide parking on
adjacent properties.



*Admiral Fell Inn: A developer an-
nounced in January, 1983, that this for-
mer industrial building at Thames and
L Broadway is to be converted into an

Thames Point, before and after renovation into luxury inn. Completion IS EXPECtEd in 1985.
apartments :





Chester Street Park and Promenade: To
accommodate the parking needs of the
developer of the former National Can
Company building at Wolfe and Ali-

« ceanna Streets the City agreed to sell a
portion of its property at Chester Street.
In return, the developer has constructed a
public shoreline promenade, landscape
a small park and plant street trees along
Chester Street. This will enhance one of
the most important links between the
community and the waterfront and pro-
vide another portion of the shoreline
walk.



93

Jackson Building: A company which
manufactures products for air filters has
rehabilitated the industrial building at
Boston Street, east of Linwood. The
company has provided a well designed
building which provides jobs and can
co-exist with future waterfront uses.

Public: The City of Baltimore has pro-
grammed a number of projects in Fells
Point and along the Canton waterfront
to encourage and support private resi-
dential and commercial development.

Street Rehabilitation and Reconstruc-
tion: There are a number of local
streets which are slated for either re-
habilitation or complete reconstruction.
These include Thames, Wolfe, Lancas-
ter, Shakespeare, Bethel, Fleet, and
Eastern. The most extensive public in-
vestment in Fells Point will be the up-
grading of streets between the existing
Jones Falls Expressway and Interstate 95
presently under construction in Canton.
At one time planned as a full, limited
access expressway passing south of
Fells Point in a tunnel, the City has pro-
posed more modest designs due to es-
calating construction costs. This would
include improvements to Fleet and Ali-
ceanna Streets and reconstruction of
Boston Street.

*Broadway Market Renovation: Now
that improvements to the market’s
south shed have been completed, the
City is undertaking various further im-
provements to the north shed. Many of
these were initiated in 1982. Recon-
struction of the north facade should be
completed in early 1984.

*Boston Street Pier: A small pier is
under censtruction on the shoreline at
Boston and O’Donnell Streets to give
public access to the water’s edge and
to provide a place for small boat moor-
ing. The project is funded by the fed-
eral Coastal Energy Impact Program
with assistance from the State’s Water-
way Improvement Division.

*Public Waterfront Access: In conjunc-
tion with several private development
projects, public promenades, walkways,
and small parks will be built along the
shoreline using funds from the federal
Urban Development Action Grant Pro-
gram, other federal and state sources,
and private capital. Designed to insure
that the public has access to the shore-
line, these improvements will be con-
structed at the same time as the accom-
panying private development.
